metadata.title: Preparation of un-promoted molybdenum HDS catalysts supported on titania by equilibrium deposition filtration: Optimization of the preparative parameters and investigation of the promoting action of titania

Experimental 2.1 Substances 2.2 Optimization of the thermal treatment of the titanium dioxide used as carrier 2.3 Regulation of the amount of molybdenum mounted on the anatase surface by adjusting the equilibration time and the pH of the impregnating suspension 2.4 Evaluation of the catalysts 2.5 Characterization of the catalysts 2.5.1 Determination of the BET−SSA and the PSD 2.5.2 Diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) 2.5.3 Thermo-programmed reduction (TPR) 2.5.4 X-ray diffraction (XRD) 2.5.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) 2.5.6 NO chemisorption 3 Results 3.1 Optimizing the thermal treatment of the titanium dioxide used as carrier 3.2 Optimizing the impregnation parameters in the frame of the EDF technique 3.2.1 Regulation of the Mo surface density of the resulted catalysts by adjusting the pH of the impregnation suspension and the equilibration time 3.2.2 Determination of catalytic activity for optimizing the surface Mo density in the catalysts and thus the relevant impregnation parameters 3.3 Texture and structure of the catalysts in their precursor oxidic state 3.3.1 Texture of the catalysts studied 3.3.2 Spectroscopic investigation of the catalysts by DRS 3.3.3 Structure of the catalysts studied 3.3.4 Reducibility of the catalysts studied 3.3.5 Investigation of the catalysts studied by XPS 3.4 Determination of the active sites in the sulfided state of the catalysts studied 4 Discussion 4.1 On the optimization of the preparative parameters 4.1.1 Thermal treatment of the anatase 4.1.2 The effect of pH of the impregnation suspension on the amount of the deposited Mo 4.1.3 Catalytic activity 4.2 The structure of the Mo supported species after each preparative-activation step 4.2.1 Supported molybdenum species in the precursor oxidic state before calcination 4.2.2 Supported molybdenum species in the precursor oxidic state after calcination 4.2.3 Supported molybdenum species in the final sulphided state 4.2.4 The promoting action of Fax: +30 2610367528. Graphical abstract A volcano trend is observed for the specific HDS activity over Mo/TiO2 catalysts vs Mo loading. The present work deals with un-promoted molybdenum hydrodesulphurization (HDS) catalysts supported on titania (anatase) which have been prepared by “Equilibrium Deposition Filtration” (EDF). The catalysts were characterized using various techniques (XRD, N2 adsoption–desorption isotherms, TPR, DRS and XPS) and evaluated at various temperatures and atmospheric pressure in a fixed bed differential reactor, using the HDS of thiophene as a probe reaction. The calcination of the carrier before its usage has been optimized. The adjustment of the impregnation parameters allowed regulating the Mo loading in the monolayer region and thus optimizing the catalytic performance. A linear decrease of the intrinsic activity with the Mo surface density and a concomitant volcano trend for the specific activity have been found. Monomer, monopodal Mo species are deposited on the anatase surface in the pH range 7.0–4.5 and polymer Mo species at pH 2. The former are transformed into tripodal ones after calcination. Thus, the monolayer capacity of the anatase surface is decreased leading to a partial association of these species into oligomer ones where the mean number of TiOMo bridges per Mo atom is lower than three. The extent of this transformation increased with the Mo surface density. The DRS, XPS and TPR results suggested that electron transfer takes place through the TiOMo bridges from the anatase surface oxygen to the Mo4d orbitals. The monomer tripodal Mo species are transformed into relatively small Mo sulphided edge clusters in tilted or perpendicular configuration bonded on the anatase surface by TiOMo and/or TiSMo bridges. The aforementioned transfer in the electronic density from the surface oxygens, and likewise from the surface sulfur, to Mo4d orbitals weakens the MoS bonds of the clusters and stabilizes S-deficient structures creating coordinative unsaturated active sites. This explains the very high intrinsic activity of these small Mo sulphided clusters. The oligomer Mo species, on the other hand, are transformed into relatively larger Mo S-deficient sulphided clusters, also with tilted or perpendicular configuration with respect to the anatase surface. The number the MoOTi and MoSTi bridges per Mo atom is smaller than that in the small Mo sulphided clusters, resulting to less coordinative unsaturated active sites per Mo atom. The above explained the aforementioned trends for the intrinsic and specific activities. Keywords Molybdenum Titania Mo/TiO2 supported catalysts Hydrodesulphurization (HDS) Intrinsic and specific activity 1 Introduction Hydrodesulphurization (HDS) is an important process for producing environmentally friendly fuels. The environmental regulations concerning sulphur specifications for transportation fuels become more and more strict; in 2008 the US standards required sulphur content 10ppm in diesel and 30ppm in gasoline. Such levels correspond to the removal of 99.9% of sulphur from typical crude containing 1.5% sulphur. On the other hand, a significant part of the world reserves consists of heavier fractions with a higher content of sulphur. The currently used hydrotreating catalysts usually consist of supported MoS2 or WS2 on γ-alumina promoted by cobalt or nickel. It has been recognized that these traditional catalysts are not adequate to meet the S levels mandated, namely for deep or ultra deep HDS. This has given rise to widespread research efforts for developing more active catalysts. Improvements of the conventional metal sulfided catalysts and the discovering of novel catalytic materials and supports are needed to meet the increasing demand for energy. The advances in the domain have been recently tabulated [1]. Moreover, a perspective on the improvement of sulphides has been recently reported [2]. The use of pure titanium dioxide or titanium dioxide based carriers seems to be a promising alternative. Earlier works have shown that a considerable increase in the HDS activity can be achieved using titanium dioxide as carrier instead of γ-alumina, provided that the activity is expressed as mole of the active phase per nm2 (intrinsic activity) [3,4]. Following this early invention a number of studies have been devoted to the preparation, characterization and testing of Mo [5–11,18], CoMo [4,6,12–17,19,20], NiMo [12,21], CoW and NiW [22] and FeMo [23–26] oxidic and sulfided species supported on titanium dioxide rich in anatase. An interesting work devoted to the catalytic HDS behavior of pure titanium dioxide should be mentioned [27]. Recently, very interesting studies have been reported dealing with the structure of the Mo species deposited on the titanium dioxide surface at each step of the preparation procedure, mainly, after impregnation, heating in air, reduction and reduction/sulphidation [28–46]. These studies may help to a better understanding of the formation and function of the active species. In almost all earlier works titanium dioxide with relatively low specific surface area (of about 50m2 g−1), available in that period, had been used. This is related to low loading of the supported phase and thus to relatively low activity per gram of the catalysts (specific catalytic activity). In order to confront this problem many studies have tried to combine the excellent intrinsic catalytic behavior of titanium dioxide with the excellent textural and mechanical properties of γ-alumina [47–70]. Two main approaches have been followed. In the first approach titanium dioxide was doped with 2–10% of γ-alumina. In this case γ-alumina acts as textural promoter. In fact, it was found that the addition of small amounts of γ-alumina in titanium dioxide prevents its sintering and the transformation of anatase to rutile. In the second case 2–10% of titanium dioxide is mounted on the γ-alumina surface considered as the main support. Various methodologies have been followed for the synthesis of the aforementioned mixed supports, including co-precipitation (co-gelation) [47–57,59,61,63,66], impregnation [57,58,62,64,66], mechanical mixing [67] and chemical vapor deposition [68–70]. Titanium dioxide has been also combined with zirconium dioxide [55,59,71–76], cerium dioxide [60] or silica [77]. A parallel research line involves the use of very high surface area mesoporous silica–titania mixed supports [78–90]. In the mean time considerable progress has been pointed out concerning preparation of titanium dioxide with quite high surface area (higher than 100m2 g−1) and this reinforced research using again pure anatase [11,14,15,17,18,20], the main polymorph of titanium dioxide. The present work deals with un-promoted molybdenum HDS catalysts supported on industrial anatase with relatively high specific surface area. The deposition of the molybdenum species was performed by “Equilibrium Deposition Filtration” (EDF). After drying, calcination and activation, the catalysts were evaluated (for the HDS of thiophene) at various temperatures, using a differential fixed bed reactor, working under atmospheric pressure. The samples were characterized using various techniques (determination and evaluation of adsoption–desorption isotherms, DRS, XRD, TPR, XPS). Although EDF had provided sub-monolayered or monolayered molybdenum catalysts supported on γ-alumina with very high Mo dispersion and thus catalytic activity [91–101], it has been scarcely applied to molybdenum catalysts supported on titanium dioxide. In the context of this method we attempt to optimize the thermal treatment of the anatase before usage, the impregnation parameters (pH, equilibration time) relevant to the interfacial deposition of the molybdenum species on the “support/impregnating solution interface” and the Mo surface density for obtaining the maximum activity. The investigation of the structure of the active site and the promoting action of the anatase surface in the light of recent theoretical and experimental findings [28–46,102,103] is also one of the main goals of the present work. 2 Experimental 2.1 Substances The following materials were used in the present work: (a) Titanium dioxide (SSA 147m2 g−1, Alfa Aesar, Johnson Matthey Company) was used as carrier. Titanium dioxide cylindrical bodies were crashed and powder particles of 90–150μm were selected by sieving. (b) Ammonium nitrate (Merck) was used for the preparation of the aqueous solutions of the indifferent electrolyte (0.1Μ) used in the adsorption experiments for regulating the ionic strength. (c) Concentrated solutions of nitric oxide (65%) and ammonium hydroxide (30%) both purchased from Carlo Erba were used for the preparation of standard solutions used in the adsorption experiments for the pH regulation. (d) Aqueous solution (0.2Μ) of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O prepared by a powder solid purchased from Alfa Aesar was used for mounting the molybdenum species on the support surface. (e) Catechol (Alfa Aesar 99% of purity) was used in the spectrophotometric determination of molybdenum. 2.2 Optimization of the thermal treatment of the titanium dioxide used as carrier The study of the influence of the calcination parameters (temperature, time and heating rate) on the texture of carrier aimed to achieve a carrier with relatively high specific surface area (SSA) and stability under the reaction conditions. A thermo programmable oven (Nabertherm B180) allowing the achievement of controlled gas atmosphere was used in all cases. The experiments were carried out under flow of synthetic air (1Lmin−1). 2.3 Regulation of the amount of molybdenum mounted on the anatase surface by adjusting the equilibration time and the pH of the impregnating suspension The catalysts were prepared following the EDF impregnation technique. In a thermostated double walled Pyrex vessel equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a perspex lid with holes for electrodes and nitrogen gas, we added 120mL of ΝΗ4ΝΟ3 solution 0.1Μ and then 30mL of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O solution 0.2M. Thus, a molybdate solution with initial Mo concentration equal to 0.04Μ was prepared. After regulating pH at a desired value (2.00, 4.50, 5.50 or 7.00) by adding small amounts of concentrated solutions of ΗΝΟ3 or NH4OH, we added 3g of anatase powder and the suspension was equilibrated under stirring. The control (change) of the pH during the deposition experiments was carried out by an automatic microburette (Metrohm, 645 multi-dosimat) equipped with a combination pH electrode. The experiments were performed at 25±0.1°C and ionic strength 0.1M adjusted by ammonium nitrate. Nitrogen gas was passed into the vessel during the experiments to prevent the dissolution of the atmospheric CO2, which would bring about a change in the pH. Four samples were taken for each pH at various times in the range of 3–48h. Moreover, for pH 4.50 four samples were taken at various times in the range of 1.5–3h. Each sample was filtrated, dried at 110°C for 4h and air calcined at 400°C for 3h. The amount of molybdenum mounted on the surface was calculated by determining spectrophotometrically (Varian Carry 3.1) the Mo concentration in the solution after filtration, following the well known catechol method [104]. By changing the equilibration pH and time we obtained sub-monolayer or monolayer EDF catalysts with different Mo loading. 2.4 Evaluation of the catalysts The calcined catalysts were activated in situ and then were evaluated by determining their catalytic activity at various temperatures and atmospheric pressure, using a differential fixed bed reactor and the HDS of thiophene as a probe reaction. The activation was performed at 400°C for 2.5h by passing through the reactor a H2S/H2 mixture (15% in Η2S). The surface was then cleaned by passing Ar through the reactor at the same temperature. Subsequently, the temperature was decreased at 250°C and the reactant mixture (hydrogen reached with thiophene vapors produced using a saturator) was passed through the reactor for 15h for obtaining a steady state. After the establishment of the steady state, gaseous samples in the reactor outlet were collected and injected in a gas chromatograph (GC/FID, Shimadzu) using a six port valve. This allowed the determination of the concentration of the unreacted thiophene and the hydrocarbons produced and thus the percentage conversion and the HDS rate of thiophene. The same procedure was followed at 300 and 350°C. 2.5 Characterization of the catalysts 2.5.1 Determination of the BET−SSA and the PSD The BET-SSA and the PSD for the carrier and the catalysts prepared (oxidic forms) were determined by conducting N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms at −196°C using a surface area and porosity analyzer (Tristar 3000-Micromeritics). Pure N2 and He were used as adsorbate and inert gas, respectively. An amount of about 100mg of a degassed sample at 250°C for 2h (using a Micromeritics degassing apparatus) was used in each experiment. The adsorption–desorption data were collected and evaluated using a Micromeritics software. The SSA was determined on the basis of (P/Pο) data collected in the range 0.01–0.03. 2.5.2 Diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) The diffuse reflectance spectra of the dried or calcined samples were recorded at room temperature in the range 200–800nm using a UV–vis spectrophotometer (Varian Cary 3.0) equipped with an integration sphere. The carrier was used as reference. The powdered samples were mounted in a quartz cell. This provided a sample thickness greater than 3mm to guarantee the “infinite” sample thickness. 2.5.3 Thermo-programmed reduction (TPR) The TPR experiments were performed in a laboratory constructed apparatus. The sample powder (0.1g, calcined form) was mounted on a quartz reactor and the gaseous mixture (H2/Ar: 5/95 v/v) was passed through the reactor (40mLmin−1) for 2h under normal temperature and pressure conditions. The temperature was then increased up to 900°C with a rate of 10°Cmin−1. The reduction of the sample leads to the decrease of the hydrogen concentration in the outlet of the reactor detected by a TCD detector. The gaseous mixture had been dried at (−95°C) before it was inserted in the detector. 2.5.4 X-ray diffraction (XRD) The XRD patterns of the powdered samples (>200 mesh) were recorded in the 2θ range of 0–110° with a rate equal to 2°min−1 using an Enraf Nonius FR 590/Inel diffractometer. A Cu Kα (λ =1.4518Å) radiation has been used. The generator was equipped with a curved position sensitive detector CPS120 of INEL. This was operated at 45kV and 25mA. 2.5.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) The photoelectron spectra (XPS) of the catalysts studied (oxidic form) were recorded using an Escalab 200R spectrometer with a hemispherical analyzer operated using a constant pass energy mode and Mg Kα X-ray radiation (hν =1253.6eV) at 10mA and 12kV. A procedure similar to that reported previously was followed for determining surface chemical characteristics (79,81,82). 2.5.6 NO chemisorption The dynamic method was used to study chemisorption of nitric oxide. The experiments were performed in a laboratory constructed apparatus. Details for the description of both apparatus and methodology have been given elsewhere [105]. 3 Results 3.1 Optimizing the thermal treatment of the titanium dioxide used as carrier Taking into account the experimental results (detailed data not shown) as well as the fact that the catalysts developed here will be tested up to 350°C where should be texturally stable, we have found as follows the optimum calcination parameters for the anatase: calcination temperature 400°C, calcination time (at 400°C) 12h and initial heating rate 18.75°Cmin−1. 3.2 Optimizing the impregnation parameters in the frame of the EDF technique 3.2.1 Regulation of the Mo surface density of the resulted catalysts by adjusting the pH of the impregnation suspension and the equilibration time Fig. 1 illustrates the variation of the Mo surface density of the resulted catalysts in the frame of the EDF technique with the pH of the impregnation suspension and the equilibration time. Several experiments have been repeated for equilibration time equal to 3h and different pHs under conditions resulting to larger amount of the prepared catalysts and test the validity of the curves illustrate in Fig. 6 under these conditions. We may observe that the increase of the equilibration time and the decrease of the pH of impregnating suspension cause an increase in the Mo surface density. The first is rather obvious while the second has been reported [100]. Therefore, we have demonstrated that a severe regulation of the Mo surface density can be easily obtained in the EDF context by adjusting the aforementioned impregnation parameters. 3.2.2 Determination of catalytic activity for optimizing the surface Mo density in the catalysts and thus the relevant impregnation parameters In order to optimize the Mo surface density obtained in the EDF context and thus the aforementioned impregnation parameters we have prepared in larger amounts several samples among those illustrated in Fig. 1. These are compiled in Table 1 . We observe that the samples synthesized cover a wide range of Mo surface density whereas three samples with the same surface density have been synthesized at the same pH but in different impregnation times. Table 2 compiles the specific rate values of the aforementioned catalysts for the HDS of thiophene at three different temperatures. Inspection of Table 2 shows that the catalysts Μο4.5 (2.0, 3), Μο3.2 (4.5, 3) and Μο4.8 (5.5, 48) are very active in almost all temperatures studied. Moreover, the catalyst Μο3.2 (4.5, 1.5) presents high activity at 350°C. As the catalysts Μο3.2 (4.5, 3) and Mo3.8 (5.5, 24) present the highest activities in the highest temperature studied and have moderate Mo loading, it seems to be the optimum non-promoted catalysts that could be synthesized in the frame of EDF. A careful observation of Table 2 clearly shows that the catalytic activity depends on the Mo surface density, and for the same Mo surface density, it depends on the impregnation parameters adopted for depositing the Mo species on the support surface. In order to trace both effects better, we have plotted the specific activity against the Mo surface density (Fig. 2 ). The curves illustrated in Fig. 2 indicate a somewhat volcano trend of the specific activity with respect to the Mo surface density. This presumably implies the competitive function of two opposite factors: the increase in the population of the active sites and the simultaneous decrease in their intrinsic activities with the Mo surface density. The latter is illustrated in Fig. 3 . The curves illustrated in Fig. 2 predict that the optimum Mo surface density is equal to 3.8 Mo atoms nm−2. This value is identical to the one of the two catalysts chosen in the present study (Μo3.2 (4.5, 3) and Mo3.8 (5.5, 12)). Closing this section we note that the careful adjustment of the impregnation parameters in the context of EDF may help us to improve the preparation procedure for obtaining a very active Mo un-promoted catalyst supported on titania. 3.3 Texture and structure of the catalysts in their precursor oxidic state 3.3.1 Texture of the catalysts studied The SSA and the PSD of the catalysts studied are respectively illustrated in the Figs. S1 and S2. Inspection of these figures shows that for the most of the catalysts studied the SSA and PSD do not change considerably after the deposition of the molybdenum species on the anatase surface and the subsequent drying and air-calcination. In three samples we observe an increase in the specific surface area from 120 to 160m2 g−1. This can be related to the increase of the pore volume. Comparison of Fig. S1 and Table 2 clearly shows that specific activity cannot be correlated with SSA. 3.3.2 Spectroscopic investigation of the catalysts by DRS The DR spectra of several dried and calcined samples are respectively illustrated in Figs. 4 and 5 . A peak at about 395nm appears in the spectra. This peak has been reported several times in the past for different transition metal oxidic species supported on titanium dioxide provided that the spectra have been recorded against pure titanium dioxide [93,106–109]. It had been generally attributed to strong interactions of the deposited oxidic species with the support [93,106–109]. For the moment there is no a convincing assignment of this peak at molecular level. This is attempted in the present work (see Section 4). The intensity of this peak increases considerably after calcination at 400°C indicating the increase of the aforementioned interactions. One could trace, though with some uncertainty, a like volcano trend for the KMS function, F(R)∞, with respect to the Mo surface density for the calcined samples (Fig. 6 ). This could be attributed to the increase of the population of the supported molybdenum species with the Mo surface density and to eventual change of the structure of the molybdenum supported species above a critical value of the Mo density. We shall return to this point in “Section 4”. 3.3.3 Structure of the catalysts studied Several calcined samples (400°C for 3h) were characterized by XRD (Fig. S3). All peaks detected is due to the anatase. The absence of any peak relevant to the molybdenum supported phase clearly indicates the high dispersion of the supported molybdenum species with sizes smaller than 4nm. 3.3.4 Reducibility of the catalysts studied The oxidic precursor of the catalysts studied were exhaustively investigated using TPR measurements. For a successful evaluation of the TPR results we have to know whether the structure of the carrier remains unchanged upon the TPR experiments. To investigate this point we have recorded XRD spectra of the carrier at various temperatures using an XRD set up working under programmed increase of temperature (10°C/min). The spectra recorded at various temperatures in the TPR range are illustrated in Fig. S4. Inspection of these spectra clearly shows that the only peaks detected are due to anatase. Therefore, one may conclude that no phase transition of the carrier takes place upon the TPR experiments. Let’s start with the TPR study of the pure carrier. The TPR curve obtained is quite complicated (Fig. S5). Following a large number of assays we have concluded that the quite complex TPR curve of anatase can be successfully deconvoluted into four simple TPR peaks reflecting the presence of four reducible kinds of Ti4+ ions. Our results do not allow an assignment of the TPR peaks to these species. However, one may assume different reducibility of the bulk Ti4+ ions from the surface ones bonded to terminal or bridged hydroxyls and from Ti4+ ions near to bulk or surface oxygen vacancies. Moreover, taking into account the amount of hydrogen required for the Ti4+ →Ti3+ transformation of all Ti4+ ions and the amount of hydrogen determined experimentally we may conclude that 4.23% of Ti4+ ions are reduced upon the TPR experiments. In addition, taking into account the amount of surface titanium ions (11.2 Ti4+ ions/nm2 [110]) and assuming that the surface titanium ions are reduced first, we may conclude that under our TPR experiments 24% of the surface Ti4+ ions are reduced. This number is greater than that calculated theoretically for the (101) and (001) crystal terminations of anatase [32,40] in the absence of supported molybdenum. This presumably suggests that a portion of hydrogen is consumed for the reduction of bulk Ti4+ ions. The TPR curve of the unsupported MoO3 is illustrated in Fig. S6. Comparison of the TPR behavior of the anatase with that to the bulk MoO3 clearly shows that the former starts to be reduced at 450°C whereas the latter is reduced above 600°C. Moreover, taking into account the amount of hydrogen required for the Mo6+ →Mo0 transformation of all Mo6+ ions and the amount of hydrogen determined experimentally we may conclude that 100% of Mo6+ ions are reduced upon the TPR experiment. The TPR curves of the catalysts studied are illustrated in Fig. S7. After attempting a large number of assays we have inferred that the quite complex TPR curves of the catalysts can be successfully deconvoluted into four simple TPR peaks. In each case the area under the total TPR curve can be attributed to the reduction of the anatase and the molybdenum supported species as well. Assuming tentatively that the reducibility of the carrier remains approximately the same as in the pure support and taking into account the anatase portion in each sample, the area of the TPR curve which is due to the presence of the supported Mo can be determined. Furthermore, taking into account the amount of hydrogen required for complete reduction of the supported Mo (Mo6+ → Mo0) and the total amount of hydrogen experimentally consumed for the reduction of the supported Mo, the total reducibility ratio (experimental/theoretical amount of hydrogen consumed) is obtained. The values of this parameter for the catalysts studied are illustrated in Table S1 (last column). The reducibility ratio can be also obtained for each of the peak of the TPR spectra using the corresponding amount of the consumed hydrogen (Table S1, columns 2–5). Finally, using the reducibility ratio for each peak we may easily calculate the mean oxidation number of the supported molybdenum after a certain number of TPR peaks using the formula: mean oxidation number=previous mean oxidation number −6×reducibility ratio. The values of the mean oxidation number are also compiled in Table S1 (columns 2–5). The values of the mean oxidation number obtained after the first and the second TPR peaks are of particular interest because they correspond to temperatures more close to that of the activation procedure compared to the temperatures of the third and fourth TPR peaks. These values are plotted against the Mo surface density (Fig. 7 ). We may observe that the mean oxidation number of the supported Mo obtained after the first and the second TPR peak increases linearly with the Mo surface density. This means that the increase in the Mo surface density causes a decrease in the reducibility of the catalysts in this temperature range. We shall return to this point in “Section 4”. 3.3.5 Investigation of the catalysts studied by XPS The detailed XP spectra of the catalysts studied in the range of the Μo3d5/2 and Μo3d3/2 photoelectrons are illustrated in Fig. S8. The spectra indicate the presence of Mo6+ in the calcined samples. Moreover, we have analyzed XP peaks due to the Ti2p3/2 and O1s photoelectrons. Using the XP spectra we have calculated the binding energies of the Μo3d5/2, Ti2p3/2 and O1s photoelectrons as well as the Mo/Ti surface atomic ratio. These are compiled in Table S2. An inspection of the energy values obtained for the Mo3d5/2 photoelectrons shows that these can be classified into two groups. The first includes the samples with the Mo surface density in the range 1.7–3.8 Mo atoms/nm2 and the second the samples with the Mo surface density in the range 4.5–5.5 Mo atoms/nm2. The mean binding energy in the first group is equal to 232.3eV while in the second 232.5eV. This difference, though too small, could imply a somewhat fine change in the structure of the Mo surface species. We shall return to this point in “Section 4”. Fig. 8 illustrates the dependence of the Mo/Ti surface atomic ratio on the Mo surface density. The obtained linear dependence indicates a rather “monolayer coverage” of the anatase surface by the molybdenum surface species even in the sample with the maximum Mo surface density. This implies the very good Mo dispersion obtained by the EDF impregnation technique. Small differences in the (Mo/Ti)XPS ratio are observed for samples with the same Mo surface density but prepared under different impregnation conditions. This indicates that the optimization of these conditions in the EDF context is quite useful. 3.4 Determination of the active sites in the sulfided state of the catalysts studied Fig. 9 presents the NO chemisorption results over the catalysts studied. It is well known that the NO uptake is a good estimate of the concentration of coordinative unsaturated sites (cus). It can be observed that NO chemisorption follows a like volcano trend, similar to that observed for the specific activity. This means that the concentration of cus is maximized in a short surface density range and then it decreases in higher surface Mo density values. 4 Discussion 4.1 On the optimization of the preparative parameters 4.1.1 Thermal treatment of the anatase As already mentioned, taking into account our experimental results (details have not been given) we have chosen as follows the optimum calcination parameters for the anatase: calcination temperature 400°C, calcination time (at 400°C) 12h, and initial heating rate 18.75°Cmin−1. Under these calcination conditions the relatively high SSA (about 120m2 g−1) and the PSD obtained for the carrier as well as the anatase structure remain practically constant upon the subsequent preparation steps (Figs. S1–S3). Moreover, these are expected to remain also constant under the more mild activation and operations conditions of the catalysts. 4.1.2 The effect of pH of the impregnation suspension on the amount of the deposited Mo As already mentioned the increase in the impregnation time and the decrease in the pH of the impregnating suspension increase the amount of the deposited Mo and thus its surface density in the resulting catalyst (Fig. 1). The influence of the impregnation time is obvious while the influence of the impregnation pH should be discussed. The old, widely accepted, view had attributed the aforementioned increase in the amount of the deposited Mo with decreasing pH to the increase of the positive charge of the carrier surface (the point of zero charge of the anatase used in this study is equal to 6). This favors the electrostatic deposition of the negatively charged molybdate species. Moreover, the decrease in pH causes the increasing transformation of the monomer to the polymer Mo species which carry to the support surface much more molybdenum atoms per molecule. This interpretation should be partially changed in the light of new findings. A recent work [29] has shown that monomer (MoO4 2−) or polymer (e.g., Mo7O24 6−) species are deposited on the anatase surface upon equilibration of the impregnating suspension. The kind of the deposited species and its relative concentration depends on the molybdenum concentration in the impregnating solution and the pH of the suspension [29]. At highest pH values (4.5–7.0) and for Mo solution concentration 4×10−2 M, used in our preparations, monomer Mo species are selectively deposited on the anatase surface [29]. These are bonded either via hydrogen bonds with the bridged surface hydroxyls of the anatase or through coordinative bonds with the terminal oxygen atoms of the anatase surface, but not electrostatically according to the old views [29]. These surface structures are exemplified in Fig. 10 for one of the majority terminations of the anatase nanocrystals. The deposition of the Mo polymer species is negligible up to pH 4.5 though its solution concentration is important at this pH value [29]. Therefore, the increase in the deposited Mo as pH decreases from 7.0 to 4.5 is due to the increasing positive charge in the interfacial region which favors the transfer of more and more negative monomer species in this region increasing thus the extent of their “reaction” with the surface oxygen of anatase. At pH 2 the electrostatic deposition of the polymer negative species prevails (Fig. 11 ) and this justifies the increase in the amount of the deposited Mo as they transfer more Mo atoms per molecule compared to the monomer Mo species [29]. 4.1.3 Catalytic activity As already mentioned the Μo3.8 (5.5, 24) catalyst is the most promising among those examined in the present work (slightly better than the Μo3.2 (4.5, 3) catalyst). Thus, this work allowed the optimization of the preparative parameter in the EDF context. However, the most interesting finding of the present work is the like volcano trend of the specific activity with respect to the Mo surface density. Surprisingly, the Mo deposition at very small pH and/or high impregnation time (Μο5.5 (2.0, 48), Μο5.0 (4.5, 48)) does not result to catalysts with high specific activity (Table 2) though under these conditions the amount of the deposited Mo is maximized in the frame of EDF. This was actually unexpected because the increase of the Mo surface density in the so called “monolayer range” would result to the increase in the specific activity. The volcano trend was attributed to the linear decrease of the intrinsic activity as the Mo density increases in the monolayer range (Fig. 3). This indicates that the activity of the sulphided Mo species formed after activation is changed with the Mo content. It seems that more active species are formed in small Mo loadings. This conclusion is in line with our observation that the anatase surface is not catalytically active under our reaction conditions. We shall come back to this point in the next sections where we shall try to establish “structure—activity” relationships utilizing our characterization results. 4.2 The structure of the Mo supported species after each preparative-activation step 4.2.1 Supported molybdenum species in the precursor oxidic state before calcination As already mentioned monomer monopodal molybdenum species are deposited on the anatase surface in the pH range 7–4.5 (Fig. 10). The deposition of the polymer Mo species prevails only at pH 2. It is interesting to discuss these surface Mo structures from the view point of the capacity of the anatase surface and the deposition results (Fig. 1, Table 1). The surface density of the terminal hydroxyl groups of the anatase is equal to 5.6 OHnm−2 [111]. The bridged hydroxyl groups have the same density [111]. Thus, the total OH density is equal to 11.2 OHnm−2. This predicts the maximum surface capacity of the anatase surface for the monomer monopodal molybdenum species without taking into account stereochemical hindrances. But this is not the case, as inspection of Fig. 1 and Table 1 show that the maximum Mo surface density obtained is only 5 Mo atoms nm−2. This indicates that a monomer monopodal Mo species covers a region of about two surface OH groups implying important stereochemical hindrance. Thus, the capacity of the anatase surface allows the formation of the so structured monolayer of Mo monomer monopodal species in the pH range 7.0–4.5. Moreover, as already mentioned the electrostatic deposition of the polymer negative species (e.g., Mo7O24 6−) prevails at pH 2. The detailed study of the adsorption at this pH has shown that 10 hydroxyl groups are required for accommodating each Mo7O24 6− ion [29]. Thus, at the maximum Mo density obtained in the present study (5.5 Mo atoms nm−2 obtained for impregnation time equal to 48h) we need only 5.5×10/7=7.86 OH nm−2. Thus, a layer of polymer Mo species can be easily formed at pH 2. It should be noted that the layer formed by the polymer Mo species is not a rigorous monolayer as the Mo atoms extended somewhat outside the surface (Fig. 11). 4.2.2 Supported molybdenum species in the precursor oxidic state after calcination The configuration of the monomer monopodal Mo species is changed after calcination as we have demonstrated in a recent study [34]. This study has shown that the hydrogen bond is transformed into coordinative bond whereas a progressive anchoring of the initially formed monopodal species into bipodal and then into tripodal units, takes place by increasing the calcination temperature (Fig. 12 ). Thus, the increase of the calcination temperature causes an increase in the number of coordinative bonds per supported Mo atom. That study has predicted that the surface is covered by the tripodal species ((TiO)3MoO) under our calcination conditions and deposition pH [34]. The formation of a monolayer of these small species is not expected to cause changes in the texture of the samples in agreement with our results (Figs. S1 and S2). Moreover, the presence of these small Mo species on the anatase surface is in line with the absence of XRD peaks owned to the Mo crystal phases (Fig. S3) and with linear dependence of the (Mo/Ti)XPS ratio with Mo surface density (Fig. 8). The increase in the TiOMo bridges per Mo atom after calcination allows explaining the increase in the value of the KMS function for the band observed at 395nm when going from the dry to the calcined samples (Figs. 4 and 5). Moreover, it allows attempting, for the first time, an assignment of this peak at molecular level. The increase in the intensity of the aforementioned band with the increase in the number of TiOMo bridges per Mo atom suggests that these bridges are presumably related to the appearance of this band. It is reasonable to assume that this band is due to “ligand (Surface Oxygen) to metal (Molybdenum)” charge (electron) transfer, well known in the coordination chemistry [112]. More precisely, the known molecular orbital (MO) diagram of the MoO4 2− species has been shown to be (σ) 2α1 <(σ) 2t2 <(π) 1e<(π) 3t2 <(π) t1 <(d) 2e<(d) 4t2, with the last two d orbitals being empty in the ground state (the sequence of the orbitals grouped in the square brackets may vary) [112]. It is generally accepted that the lowest, long wavelength feature in the electronic spectrum will be the 1t1 →2e ligand to metal charge transfer (LMCT) transition (1T2 → 1A1). The longest wavelength LMCT band of MoO4 2− appears at about 240nm, assigned to the 1t1 →2e transition [112]. The DR spectra in our case show a band at 395nm which is assigned to the oxygen–molybdenum charge transfer transition. The appearance of this band is actually a strong evidence for the formation of the TiOMo bridges mentioned before. The unusually long wavelength (low energy) of this LMCT transition indicates that the ligand (OTi, or TiOTi) has become more readily oxidisable. In effect, this electron transfer seems indeed plausible if one takes into account that the surface, bridging and terminal, oxygens of the anatase carry negative charge whereas molybdenum has an oxidation number equal to +6 in the surface Mo complexes. The oxygen charge has been calculated by different groups using ab-initio DFT calculations (see a recent review reported by our group [113] and the references [66,67,102,261] there in). Finally, it has been reported that the high Lewis basicity of the bridging oxygens of anatase involved in the MoOTi bridges favors transfer of electronic density from the O2c2p orbitals to the Mo4d orbitals [41]. The above corroborate our assignment that shall be used for explaining several experimental results. The transformation of the monopodal into tripodal monomer Mo species requires three instead of one receptor sites per monomer Mo species bringing about a decrease in the anatase surface capacity. This causes the progressive transformation of the monomer into oligomer Mo species [34]. The increasing transformation of Mo monomer tripodal species into the Mo oligomer ones with the Mo surface density would explain the like volcano trend observed for the variation of the KMS function at 395nm with the Mo surface density (Fig. 6). The increase in the Mo surface density gives rise to two opposite effects concerning the population of the TiOMo bridges, related to the intensity of the band at 395nm. This population is increased due to the increase in the number of the tripodal species whereas it is decreased due to the progressive transformation of tripodal species into the oligomer ones. The number of the TiOMo bonds per Mo atom is, in effect, larger in the former than in the latter Mo species. The function of these two opposite effects causes the appearance of the volcano trend mentioned before. It is important to note that the maximum in the volcano curve is observed at 3.8 Mo atoms nm−2. This value is very close to the maximum value predicted for the surface density of the Mo monomer tripodal species (11.2 OHnm−2 =3.73 Mo atoms nm−2). Above this value the contribution of the oligomer species becomes more important. Presumably, the considerable change in the stucture of the supported Mo species above the aforementioned value could be also taken into account for explaining the change in the mean binding energy of the Mo3d5/2 photoelectrons from 232.3eV (determined in the samples with Mo surface density ≤3.8 Mo atoms nm−2) to 232.5eV (determined in the samples with Mo surface density higher than this critical value). In fact, the relatively high number of MoOTi bridges per Mo atom in the samples with relatively low Mo density favors the transfer of electronic density from the surface oxygen to molybdenum justifying thus the smaller value for the Mo3d5/2 binding energy observed in these samples. As the increase in the Mo surface density hinders the transfer of electron density from the surface oxygen to molybdenum it is expected to decrease the mean reducibility of the supported Mo, in full agreement with our experimental results (Fig. 7). 4.2.3 Supported molybdenum species in the final sulphided state The oxidic precursor species described above are transformed into sulphided or oxo−sulphided species after activation. The discussion of the structure of these species is based on literature results mainly derived for catalysts with Mo surface density and activation conditions similar to our samples. The structure of the species formed on the surface of titanium dioxide have been investigated using HRTEM [6–8,20,43,44] and more recently by ab-initio DFT calculations [41,46]. The application of HRTEM on various Mo sulfide/anatase samples with Mo surface densities in the range of the samples studied by us had indicated the presence of very small Mo sulfide clusters, with a single or 2–3 Mo layers depending on the Mo surface density. In particular Ramirez et al. [6] identified very small Mo sulfide clusters (thickness 0.625nm, length 2.5nm) situated in a plane perpendicular to the carrier surface. This morphology could imply that these clusters are edge bonded to the anatase surface. Moreover, tilted orientations had been observed by electronic microscopy for Mo sulphided clusters supported on titanium dioxide catalysts [43,44]. Ab-initio DFT calculations shed more light on the structure of the Mo clusters supported on anatase surface. Arrouvel et al. [41] studied the thermodynamic stability of seven triangular Mo6S n , Mo-edged, clusters (n =24,15,14,13,11 and 10) on the perfect (101) and (001) faces of anatase. The first cluster exposes Mo-edges with 100% S coverage (Mo6S24) and the second Mo-edges with 50% S coverage (Mo6S15). The third, fourth, fifth, sixth and seventh cluster has derived from the second cluster and presents one corner (Mo6S14,c), one edge (Mo6S14,e), one edge and one corner (Mo6S13,c,e), three edge (Mo6S11,3e) and one corner and three edge (Mo6S10,c,3e) vacancies. Edge bonded S-deficient clusters (n =10–14) in a tilted or vertical configurations with respect to the (101) surface are stabilized for P H2/P H2S ratio similar to that used under activation conditions. More and more S-deficient clusters are stabilized as the P H2/P H2S ratio decreases. A schematic representation of the Mo6S13,c,e cluster in a tilted configuration and of the Mo6S10,c,3e, cluster in a vertical configuration is illustrated, as an example, in Fig. 13 (a) and (b), respectively, for the (101) surface. The formation of MoOTi and MoSTi (Fig. 13(a)) or MoOTi (Fig. 13(b)) bridges is obvious in these supported structures. Similar but not identical S-deficient clusters are stabilized on the (001) anatase orientation [40,41]. The above theoretical findings concern very small Mo clusters contained 3 Mo atoms per edge, corresponding to a particle size of about 0.6nm. The extension of this study to larger and more real clusters [41] showed that S-deficient, edge-bonded clusters are thermodynamically stable up to 14 Mo atoms per edge corresponding to length smaller than 4.5nm (9nm diameter in hexagonal particles). These may present a perpendicular or tilted configuration, thanks to the aforementioned chemical ligand effect of the anatase surface. It should be noted that these S-deficient, edge-bonded clusters are not thermodynamically stable even for small clusters with 4 Mo atoms per edge for γ-alumina. This finding is in agreement with relevant microscopic observations [43,44] and should be taken into account for explaining the relatively high intrinsic HDS activity of titania with respect to γ-alumina. The stability of perpendicular Mo sulphided clusters on the (100) and (001) crystal faces of anatase was also confirmed for small S-edged S-deficient Mo6S n clusters (n =16–11) [46]. These are mainly anchored on the aforementioned faces through one or few TiOMo or TiSMo bonds. Hydrogen SH bonds with the anatase surface hydroxyls stabilize the clusters in some cases. 4.2.4 The promoting action of anatase and the interpretation of the like volcano trend obtained for the specific activity On the basis of the considerations concerning the structure of the Mo supported species, it seems to us reasonable to assume that upon activation the monomer tripodal Mo species, formed after calcination (Fig. 12), are transformed into relatively small Mo sulphided edge clusters in tilted or perpendicular configuration bonded on the anatase surface by TiOMo and/or TiSMo bridges (e.g., Fig. 13). This implies a low extent association upon activation besides sulphidation. The number of the bridges per Mo atom is maximized in these quite small Mo sulfided clusters. As already mentioned, electronic density is transferred from the surface oxygens, and likewise from the surface sulfur, of the aforementioned bridges to Mo4d orbitals. This is expected to weaken the MoS bonds of the clusters. Thus, this transfer can be taken into account for the stabilization of the S-deficient structures mentioned above and the formation of the coordinative unsaturated sites considered as the active ones in HDS. Thiophene is adsorbed on these sites. This explains the very high intrinsic activity of these small Mo sulphided clusters (Fig. 3). On the other hand it seems plausible to assume that the oligomer Mo species formed after calcination, are transformed into relatively larger Mo S-deficient sulphided clusters, also with tilted or perpendicular configuration with respect to the anatase surface. The number of the MoOTi and MoSTi bridges per Mo atom is obviously smaller than that in the small Mo sulphided clusters bringing about the formation of less coordinative unsaturated sites per Mo atom. Therefore, the bigger S-deficient structures are less active than the smaller ones. Taking into account the above, we may understand the trends observed for the intrinsic (Fig. 3) and specific activity (Fig. 2). In fact, the relative contribution of the larger and thus less active Mo sulphided clusters increases with the Mo surface density following the trend of the oligomer Mo species in the precursor oxidic state. As a result, the intrinsic activity decreases linearly with the Mo surface density. On the other hand, the like volcano trend observed for the specific activity may be attributed to two opposite effects caused by the increase in the Mo surface density: the increase in the amount of the supported active species and the increasing participation of less active species. It is important to stress that the maximum of the volcano curve corresponds to a complete monomolecular layer of Mo mononuclear tripodal species. The above were corroborated by the NO chemisorption trend. In fact, the titration of the coordinative unsaturated sites (active sites) with the NO showed a like-volcano trend for the NO chemisorption over the catalysts studied with the Mo surface density (Fig. 9) indicating that the concentration of active sites reaches a maximum and then it decreases. 5 Conclusions The following conclusions can be drawn from the present work: 1. The study of the heat treatment of anatase allowed the optimization of the calcination conditions whereas the careful adjustment of the impregnation parameters (pH, impregnation time) in the EDF context allowed regulating of the Mo loading in the monolayer region and thus optimizing the catalytic performance. 2. Monomer monopodal Mo species are deposited on the anatase surface in the pH range (7.0–4.5) and polymer Mo species (e.g., Mo7O24 6−) at pH 2. The former are transformed into tripodal ones after calcination. This decreases the monolayer capacity of the anatase surface and gives rise to an association of these species into oligomer ones where the mean number of TiOMo bridges is lower than 3 encountered in the monomer tripodal species. The extent of this transformation increases with the Mo surface density. 3. Electron transfer from the anatase surface oxygen to the Mo4d orbitals takes place through the TiOMo bridges of the aforementioned Mo species. This electron transfer is corroborated by DRS, XPS and TPR results. 4. The monomer tripodal Mo species are transformed into relatively small Mo sulphided edge clusters in tilted or perpendicular configuration bonded on the anatase surface by TiOMo and/or TiSMo bridges. The number of the bridges per Mo atom is maximized in these quite small Mo sulfided clusters. The aforementioned transfer in the electron density from the surface oxygens, and likewise from the surface sulfur, to Mo4d orbitals weakens the MoS bonds of the clusters and stabilizes S-deficient structures creating coordinative unsaturated sites considered as the active ones in HDS. This explains the very high intrinsic activity of these small Mo sulphided clusters. 5. The oligomer Mo species are transformed into relatively larger Mo S−deficient sulphided clusters, also with tilted or perpendicular configuration with respect to the anatase surface. The number of the MoOTi and MoSTi bridges per Mo atom is smaller than that in the small Mo sulphided clusters resulting to less coordinative unsaturated sites per Mo atom and thus to S-deficient structures less active than the smaller ones. 6. The above explained the linear decrease of the intrinsic activity with the Mo surface density and the concomitant like volcano trend of the specific activity. coredata.dc:description: The present work deals with un-promoted molybdenum hydrodesulphurization (HDS) catalysts supported on titania (anatase) which have been prepared by “Equilibrium Deposition Filtration” (EDF). The catalysts were characterized using various techniques (XRD, N2 adsoption–desorption isotherms, TPR, DRS and XPS) and evaluated at various temperatures and atmospheric pressure in a fixed bed differential reactor, using the HDS of thiophene as a probe reaction. The calcination of the carrier before its usage has been optimized. The adjustment of the impregnation parameters allowed regulating the Mo loading in the monolayer region and thus optimizing the catalytic performance. A linear decrease of the intrinsic activity with the Mo surface density and a concomitant volcano trend for the specific activity have been found. Monomer, monopodal Mo species are deposited on the anatase surface in the pH range 7.0–4.5 and polymer Mo species at pH 2. The former are transformed into tripodal ones after calcination. Thus, the monolayer capacity of the anatase surface is decreased leading to a partial association of these species into oligomer ones where the mean number of TiOMo bridges per Mo atom is lower than three. The extent of this transformation increased with the Mo surface density. The DRS, XPS and TPR results suggested that electron transfer takes place through the TiOMo bridges from the anatase surface oxygen to the Mo4d orbitals. The monomer tripodal Mo species are transformed into relatively small Mo sulphided edge clusters in tilted or perpendicular configuration bonded on the anatase surface by TiOMo and/or TiSMo bridges. The aforementioned transfer in the electronic density from the surface oxygens, and likewise from the surface sulfur, to Mo4d orbitals weakens the MoS bonds of the clusters and stabilizes S-deficient structures creating coordinative unsaturated active sites. This explains the very high intrinsic activity of these small Mo sulphided clusters. The oligomer Mo species, on the other hand, are transformed into relatively larger Mo S-deficient sulphided clusters, also with tilted or perpendicular configuration with respect to the anatase surface. The number the MoOTi and MoSTi bridges per Mo atom is smaller than that in the small Mo sulphided clusters, resulting to less coordinative unsaturated active sites per Mo atom. The above explained the aforementioned trends for the intrinsic and specific activities.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation of un-promoted molybdenum HDS catalysts supported on titania by equilibrium deposition filtration: Optimization of the preparative parameters and investigation of the promoting action of titania
